clinical_study.official_title: Dose Response Relationship of Dexmedetomidine in Decreasing Post Operative Analgesic Requirements in the Pediatric Tonsillectomy Patient

brief_summary.textblock: The hypothesis of this study is that the administration of an intra-operative dose of dexmedetomidine will result in adequate analgesia without respiratory depression thereby resulting in an early discharge from the post anesthetic care unit following adenotonsillectomy.

detailed_description.textblock:
Dexmedetomidine, an alpha 2 agonist provides some analgesia without respiratory depression. Children undergoing tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy occasionally have episodes of respiratory obstruction in the recovery room following administration of opioids.
As dexmedetomidine provides some analgesia without respiratory depression,an intra-operative dose of dexmedetomidine may provide adequate analgesia without significant side effects thereby allowing for quick post operative recovery.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Amount of Post-Operative Rescue Morphine Required for Analgesia
primary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to discharge from PACU, up to 1 hour

secondary_outcome.measure: Morphine Rescue Doses Needed by Participants
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to discharge from PACU, up to 1 hour
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects with a Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale score greater than 8 received rescue morphine doses of 25 ug/kg IV at 10-minute intervals until the score was less than 8. Minimum and Maximum values: minimum score: 4 & maximum score: 13. The higher the score ( > 8), the greater the pain appreciated by the patient.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to PACU until room air saturations greater than or equal to 95% for 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The subjects were then transported to the PACU with supplemental oxygen. Oxygen administration was continued after extubation until the patient was awake and could sustain room air saturations greater than 95% for 5 minutes. Duration of oxygen requirement was recorded as the time from tracheal extubation to cessation of oxygen supplementation in the PACU.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to discharge from PACU, no time limit
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were considered ready for discharge from the PACU when they attained an Aldrete score of 9 or more and were free from pain, nausea, and vomiting. Aldrete score ranges form 0 to 10 and patients greater than 8 are deemed satisfactory for discharge from the PACU

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Emergence Agitation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to discharge from PACU, no time limit
secondary_outcome.description: Patients in the PACU who were crying, restless, disoriented, unresponsive to the parent's voice, with non-purposeful thrashing movements requiring additional personnel to prevent bodily harm, and inconsolable even after parental presence, rescue analgesia and additional measures of comfort were considered to have emergence agitation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Postoperative Complications
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to discharge from PACU, up to 1 hour
secondary_outcome.description: Post-operative complications including emesis, prolonged oxygen requirement or post- tonsillectomy bleed assessed up to 1 hour in PACU

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children between ages 3 and 17 years with American Society of Anesthesiology classification 1 or 2.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Children less than 3 years
- Children with uncorrected cardiac lesions
- Children with heart block or liver impairment
- Children with American Society of Anesthesiology Class 3 or 4.
